PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in the Vietnam war from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.

Your humble petitioners pray that the Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and the members of the Senate. We the undersigned oppose changes to general medical practice contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act. We believe there should not be two levels of Medicare rebates for general practice. We also believe there should be upgraded undergraduate training and postgraduate training for general practitioners to obtain appropriate skills. Current and proposed Medicare rebates for general practitioner services are inadequate, and there should be appropriate Medicare rebates for doctors who provide out of hours consultations.
Therefore we humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will support general practitioners to achieve the above.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by Western Australia Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: The Hawke Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill concerning Credit Reference Reporting will

(1) prohibit many legitimate uses of credit information by organisations such as real estate agents, mortgage underwriters, insurance companies, businesses selling goods on credit, and companies renting or leasing goods and equipment
(2) add to the cost of business and increase interest rates, and insurance charges and lead to over commitment by borrowers

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should: reject Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill to enable businesses to have access to credit information they require to make sensible commercial decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, will be absent from the chamber for Question Time this week on official Government business overseas. Senator Evans will be attending the United Nations General Assembly in New York. The Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, will also be absent from the chamber for Question Time today. He is attending the meeting of the Australia-New Zealand Environment Council in Victoria. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Evans in relation to his own portfolio or those he represents should be directed to me. Those questions which would normally be directed to Senator Richardson should be directed to Senator Ray.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that last Thursday a French registered Air Maritime Boeing 737 with French pilots operating a scheduled Sydney-Melbourne internal air service accepted a standard instrument departure via Wollongong from runway 16 at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport? Is it a fact that, instead of flying the correct route, the French crew turned right, thereby breaching lateral separation standards? Is the Minister aware that, despite urgent calls from an alert Sydney air traffic control, the pilots persisted with their error? What disciplinary action has been taken against these pilots? Not only could there have been a collision between two commercial airliners with great loss of life, but the accident could have occurred over southern suburban Sydney, possibly over a school, and even more lives could have been lost.

—I am advised as of today that the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation has not yet received a formal report on this incident. Therefore it is not possible to establish who, if anyone, was at fault. On the basis of information received so far the Bureau does not believe that air safety was in any way compromised. I appreciate that there are a number of specifics in the honourable senator's question and I will endeavour, as soon as there has been a fuller investigation of the matter, to provide him with an answer as soon as possible.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. The Minister's answer now raises even more profound questions. How is the administration of air safety monitored in this country? This incident, accurately reported in the press, is now many days old. As a further supplementary, is it not a fact that if an Australian crew made an error of this magnitude it would have been grounded on the spot pending the outcome of an inquiry?

—Of course I cannot answer the second part of the question, nor can Senator MacGibbon, although he tried to implicitly in his question. In so far as the first part is concerned, I will provide an answer, together with the other answer that I am getting for him.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer to the article in the Age on Saturday about alleged unauthorised exchanges of confidential personal information amongst public servants in a variety of departments and agencies, including the Australian Customs Service, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Australian Electoral Commission and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, which it was said has been going on for 10 years. A further item in today's Age alleges that the exchange might also have included Department of Social Security information. Does it appear that the allegations in the articles are correct? What is being done to stop this disgraceful practice and to determine who has been responsible? Will the Government make it clear that public servants who consider indulging in such activities are not a law unto themselves and that their actions are strongly disapproved of?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the very speedy and very forceful response by relevant Federal Government Ministers to the allegation of disclosures, made initially in the Age and, apparently, according to Senator Coates, again today, indicates that this Government disapproves in the strongest possible terms of the disclosure of confidential information, held by the Public Service on behalf of citizens, in a way which would lead those citizens to fear that the confidentiality and privacy of that information might be breached by those public servants who have an obligation to serve their interests and not abuse the trust reposed in them. There is no doubt that such conduct--
—They did. That is just what they did.

—Of course, Senator Peter Baume wishes to take the place of the Australian Federal Police and others in investigating this matter. It is true that allegations have been made. The way they have been put together by David Wilson suggests that, unfortunately, he is reporting matters of fact. I believe the matter needs to be investigated by the Australian Federal Police. That is being pursued vigorously, and has been since these matters were first brought to the notice of the Australian Federal Police.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also important to know that the Privacy Commissioner, Mr Kevin O'Connor, is aware of the matter. Of course, the Government will assist Mr O'Connor and facilitate any investigation that he considers appropriate. I believe he has announced that he will be auditing the key departments concerned with a view to ensuring that they have in place proper security safeguards to prevent these sorts of unauthorised disclosures. Those public servants who engage, or have in the past engaged, in these sorts of practices need to know not only that this Parliament is horrified at the thought that our explicit intentions, as contained in, for example, the Privacy Act, passed by this Parliament late last year, have been ignored, but also, in so far as the activity might amount to offences under the various Commonwealth statutes, that they will be pursued. Stringent penalties are in place for those who unlawfully disclose personal information-I believe imprisonment for up to two years, for example. I can assure Senator Coates that the Government is adamant that the Australian Federal Police and the Privacy Commissioner should pursue their various investigations with the full support of the Government. We look to the results of those investigations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it a fact that the six French pilots recruited to fly British Aerospace 146-four-engined jet airliners-for Airlines of Western Australia were licensed to fly under examination conditions that were far less than those applying to Australian pilots? Is it a fact that since operations into many Western Australian ports serviced by this airline are outside controlled airspace-that is, with a busy mix of other aircraft whose position and intentions may or, more likely, may not be known-the Civil Aviation Authority requires pilots to fly 50 hours in command under supervision on these routes before licensing them? Did these six French pilots fulfil this requirement or was the requirement waived?
—I am not familiar with the details of this matter. I will obtain an answer for the honourable senator as quickly as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of criticism made recently in the Australian Financial Review of the effects of an inefficient taxi industry on Australia's attractiveness to overseas tourists? What does the Government intend to do about this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did read in today's Australian Financial Review a letter to the editor about the market value of--
—There was an editorial.
—No, it was a letter. It was not an editorial.
—But there was an editorial earlier.

—Earlier, yes. I was going to say that it is not the first time that there has been comment within the last week. Senator Alston has reminded me that there was, in fact, an editorial in the Australian Financial Review. I had forgotten that it was in the Australian Financial Review. Both the letter and the previous newspaper comment draw attention to what is a pretty outrageous rort. The letter demonstrates that the rort is most outrageous in Queensland, which would not particularly surprise anybody who is familiar with the history of government in Queensland, the principal objective of which is to cream a bit off every taxpayer and a bit more off the Federal Government and then deliver it to National Party cronies. But given that the taxi plates are said to be worth a quarter of a million dollars on the Gold Coast, and that that price by definition represents nothing more than capitalised economic rent-that is, the capitalised value of the excessive fares which taxis charge-I would have thought that Senator Stone, who is a person of some substance in the Queensland National Party, might have actually tried to do something about this. As far as I know, he has done absolutely nothing. The letter in today's Australian Financial Review is so good that I ought to quote a few paragraphs from it. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: A prime example of the correlation between restricted entry and goodwill value exists in the Gold Coast where licence transfers now cost around $250,000, easily the highest in Australia.
The Gold Coast, a high-growth area with a local and tourist population exceeding 200,000, is serviced by one taxi co-op with 145 taxis on its register.
The letter continues:
The department prohibits taxis from any adjoining taxi districts to ply for hire across their defined borders, and also refuses to transfer licences from district to district.

I interpolate that this is, of course, totally consistent with the laws or regulations which were promulgated in Queensland about 10 years ago regarding bakeries. In order to protect the captive market that some National Party crony had in every country town in Queensland it became illegal to transport bread from one district to another. I return to the letter:
The effect of all of these restraints of market forces is to reward the lucky Gold Coast licence owner with a capital gains bonanza, plus assured cash-flow, free of any competition.

I add, of course, that if the Opposition's tax policy, due to be announced next week, recommits the Opposition to its silly proposal that people would not pay any capital gains tax after they have had an asset for five years, the people who pick up these licences will, after five years, be able to flog them off, make a quarter of a million dollars capital gain, and pay absolutely no tax on it, thereby further aggravating the rort. If I am wrong and Senator Stone has made some effort-he is, I would say, the most significant member of the Queensland National Party these days-to clean up this rort within the National Party of Queensland, I look forward to hear him explaining, by way of a personal explanation at the end of Question Time, what he has done. In the absence of such a personal explanation I must assume that Senator Stone has decided, as he once put it, to adopt the Nelsonian approach to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is the use of Australian Defence Force troops against Australian citizens at the United States base at Nurrungar in South Australia another symptom of Australia's rising militarism? Does the Government continue to maintain--
—You are ratting on your own side's matter of public importance.
—Can you control this rabble, Mr President?
—Order!

—Does the Government continue to maintain that Nurrungar is for verification purposes rather than nuclear war fighting? If so, what was the need for bringing in troops to defend a benign verification base? What has the United States Government or the Australian Government got to hide?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Sanders's questions, the answer to the first is no; the answer to the second is yes. In regard to the first part of his third question, the Australian defence forces were there to act as a reserve to release South Australian police and Australian Protective Service personnel to the outer perimeter. In relation to the purposes of the base, I refer him to the Prime Minister's and Mr Beazley's statement of 22 November 1988.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Did the Minister hear reports on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) radio program this morning of criticism by National Party frontbencher, Mr John Sharp, of the level of Commonwealth funding for roads? Will the Minister recommend to Cabinet an increase in roads funding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly did hear on the wireless this morning-indeed on an ABC wireless program-a report that Mr Sharp had been saying that road funding should be increased by 30 per cent. If that were to be done, it would cost just over $400m extra. Whether the Federal Government or taxpayers ought to be spending another $400m on roads is, I suppose, a matter for debate. The level of road funding from Federal government sources, in real terms, of course, is now higher than it has been through most of the period, indeed almost all of the period--
—Rubbish! Absolute rubbish!

—It is not. Senator Boswell should check a few things. If there are insufficient funds in Queensland to provide decent roads, I suggest that Senator Boswell should arrange for some of the money which is presently spent on providing a Rolls Royce road to `The Ten Mile' property, to be diverted to some more worthy cause. It should not be squandered in the way that it is. To the best of my knowledge, nobody else uses that road, other than, of course, the occupier of `The Ten Mile', and we all know who that is, do we not?
—It is not even bituminised.

—I can see that Senator Boswell knows a good deal about the road to `The Ten Mile'. It is not even bitumenised, he said. A lot of farm tracks-which is about all that that one is-are not even formed. That one, I understand, is a very high grade, non-sealed road for a farm track. But it is, of course, a very special farm track.

ANSWER.PARA: The last point I want to make is that when-I should say if, or when or when/if-the Opposition ever gets around to releasing its taxing and spending policies, I hope that in that $1.2 billion, which we have been assured by Mr Peacock it will propose be taken off expenditure, it has made allowance for the $400m which Mr Sharp says should be added to expenditure for roads. I trust that the $1.2 billion figure will be a net figure and that the $400m will be properly accounted for. If that is not the case, of course we will have to conclude that the Opposition is just back to its old habit of speaking with a forked tongue.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE: SAFETY STANDARDS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Do members of the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) operate to the same safety standards as prescribed by the Civil Aviation Authority with respect to hours on duty and hours flown when they are operating in the civilian airline role?
—I understand so, but I will check that answer and provide it in more detail.

—My question, to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, relates to Defence Minister Beazley's action in sending Australian Defence Force (ADF) troops to Nurrungar on Saturday, 30 September. Do all members of the ADF automatically have full security clearance to enter all parts of the so-called joint facilities-Pine Gap, North West Cape and Nurrungar? Will the Minister advise the Senate under which Acts, regulations and other related documents he issued instructions for the movement of Defence Force personnel to Nurrungar and under which Acts, regulations and other related documents he issued further instructions for the use of Defence Force personnel against civilians at Nurrungar? Will the Minister table the relevant documents including his instructions? If not, why not? Has the Minister for Defence, by calling in troops to deal with civilian demonstrators, created a dangerous precedent which could be a threat to the civil liberties of any Australians who choose to oppose the Government? Finally I ask the Minister why he will not admit that Nurrungar has both an offensive and a defensive capability as far as United States strategic planning is concerned instead of continuing to perpetuate the myth that Nurrungar exists only for arms control agreements that were made after the base was established.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the question is no. However, those members of the Australian Defence Force who entered Nurrungar had the appropriate security clearances and were properly authorised to do so. The second part of the question, which contains about four questions, requires a large amount of detail. I will refer that to the Minister for Defence for a further answer. In relation to whether the actions have created a precedent, the answer is no. In relation to the last part of the honourable senator's question as to the purposes of the base, I refer her to the Prime Minister's and Mr Beazley's statement of 22 November 1988.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it a fact that some pilots have been transferred from Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd, for whom they flew on the Coastwatch program for the Australian Customs Service, to another Ansett company and will convert to fly British Aerospace 146 aircraft? Is it a fact that the ground school for the conversion course for the BA146 takes four weeks and that these pilots have completed it in eight days? As these Coastwatch pilots had been flying light propeller-driven twin-engined six-seat Shrike Commanders and the BA146 is a heavy four-engined jet airliner carrying about 100 passengers, can the Minister assure the Senate that safety has not been compromised?

—There have been a lot of allegations in newspapers and elsewhere about alleged breaches of safety standards in the last week or so. In so far as this particular incident is concerned, I will have inquiries made of the airlines and of the Civil Aviation Authority to see whether this particular allegation has any substance or not. Clearly, some of the allegations may have some substance in them; many of them have not. Many of them emanate from sources concerned to exacerbate the existing situation-a line that the Opposition has picked up with alacrity, having failed elsewhere in respect of the pilots dispute.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Can the Minister assure the Senate that, as a consequence of the Government's compliance with the transfer of pilots from the Coastwatch program for the quick fix and safety risk pilot training, the Coastwatch program has not also been subjected to quick fix and safety risk?
—I said I would provide an answer about this matter and I will do so, including that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I refer to reports yesterday of calls by three members of the Queensland Public Accounts Committee for the sacking of the Minister for Land Management, Mr Harper, over his administration of drought relief funds. Was the decision of the Commonwealth Government to remove the eligibility of drought relief for funding under the national disaster relief arrangements related to Mr Harper's mismanagement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the last part of the question, the decision taken by Cabinet and announced in the April statement, on my recommendation, that drought relief be removed from the national disaster relief arrangements program was made partly because of the maladministration by Mr Harper, but maladministration of this program in Queensland goes back before Mr Harper's time to the period when Mr Neil Turner was the Minister for Primary Industries. Indeed, it was during Mr Turner's stewardship that the first example of gross abuse of this program was brought to my attention. That was back in 1986, when a Mr Behan-no relation, I believe, to Senator Beahan-who was a north Queensland National Party apparatchik, the north Queensland organiser I think, received a $150,000 loan at about 4 per cent interest when the property which he then owned did not meet the requirements. The $150,000 loan was described by Mr Turner, I think it was-although it may have been Mr Menzel, a National Party MLA-as a lousy loan. To people who are used to picking up brown paper bags with $50,000 and $100,000 in them, a $150,000 loan might not seem to be very much, but $150,000 to most Australians, especially at 4 per cent interest, seems to be a very major concession.

ANSWER.PARA: The maladministration has, of course, continued under Mr Harper and was focused very effectively in a report written, as we now know, by a Queensland Department of Primary Industries public servant called Mr Dan Daly which was leaked about December of last year, tabled in the Senate, and I think also tabled in the House of Representatives by Mr Kerin. That report showed that some areas of Queensland had been drought declared for more than half of the last 25 years, that some individual owners had been paid more than $300,000 in one year, and so on. The Queensland Public Accounts Committee investigated this report and Mr Daly's subsequent transfer and demotion within the Department. This Public Accounts Committee report was the subject of a news item in the Courier-Mail on 28 September. I will just quote a couple of sentences from the Courier-Mail report:
Mr Daly was exonerated in the committee's report.
The committee said Mr Daly had been moved from his job as head of the drought section secretariat without justification.
It also said:
`In the course of its inquiry, the committee has . . . substantially confirmed the concerns expressed by Mr Daly in his December 1988 memo.
`The committee believes that his arbitrary removal from the position of Officer in Charge, Drought Secretariat, was not justified.'

The final point I want to make is that one would have thought that somebody like Mr Harper, having been caught red-handed mal- administering public money to the extent that he has, would have had the decency to keep his head down for a while. But he was quoted in last week's Bulletin as saying that the Federal Government ought to be providing squillions of extra Commonwealth dollars in order to build more water storages along the east coast of Australia and particularly, of course, the north-eastern coast of Australia-the Queensland coast-so that the National Party could hand out water licences to more of its cronies who happen to hold land in the potentially irrigable areas. This, of course, is another way of generating economic rent with the expenditure of Federal taxpayers' funds and then transferring it to the pockets of National Party apparatchikis in north Queensland. It is similar, of course, to the system which prevails on the Gold Coast, in the southern part of Queensland, for transferring money from people who hire taxis to the pockets of those who are issued the plates.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Since the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) is now charging passengers to fly with it in a regular public transport role, I ask: Does the Hercules C130 aircraft meet the certification requirements laid down for regular public transport aircraft? Are any Hercules flying on regular public transport services anywhere else in the world? —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to overseas reports which claim that a widely used sleeping drug, Halcion, is responsible for causing bizarre side effects, including hallucinations, amnesia and other disturbing behavioural disorders? Can the Minister confirm whether the drug, Halcion, or any generic equivalent is available in Australia? As Halcion is a widely used sleeping preparation, will the Minister take action to verify the allegations against this drug and, if necessary, take appropriate action to protect patients in Australia?

—I am aware that bizarre side effects of the type mentioned have been reported in association with the use of the drug, Halcion. These side effects were given prominence first during 1979 in newspaper reports of occurrences in the Netherlands. Since then there have been occasional reports in the scientific press and in the lay press. Halcion has been marketed in Australia since 28 August this year. No generic equivalents are available. Approval to market Halcion followed a careful and lengthy consideration by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee of the Netherlands' experience and of all data to 1987. The bizarre side effects were of low frequency and not remarkably different from those known to occur with other sleeping drafts of the related benzodiazepine group. To reduce potential over-dosage which might increase the possibility of side effects, only the lowest strength tablet containing 0.125 milligrams was approved. Also the recommended initial dose in Australia is half of that in the United States of America. The Australian product information specifically warns prescribers about the possibility of the occurrence of amnesia and of paradoxical reactions, including hallucinations and acute psychotic behaviour. The Australian Drug Evaluation Committee maintains surveillance of the drug through the adverse reactions reporting scheme. The Committee will be given the results of the review by the Food and Drug Administration of the United States when it becomes available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware that on 1987-88 housing loan figures-and I apologise that I do not have more recent ones-the Government's deal with the big banks to fix the housing loan interest rate at 17 per cent would leave out more home borrowers, in excess of 157,000, than it protects, which is approximately 110,000? Can the Minister explain why the Government has chosen this highly selective method of holding down some interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that Senator Haines again purports to be on the side of the little person. I remind the Senate that in 1984, I believe it was, Senator Haines voted in the Senate to allow crooks like the Kelly brothers, who had been running cherry-picker schemes-fraudulent so-called superannuation schemes-to keep their ill-gotten gains, that is, to claim their payments into these fraudulent so-called superannuation schemes as a deduction from taxable income, but to then pick up all the money themselves because they made sure that none of the employees ever qualified for it. So this defence of the little person should always be seen against that sort of background.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been asked why the Government made this arrangement for the banks and not for other financial institutions. It is for the very good reason that what used to be called the statutory reserve deposits (SRDs), which are now called non-callable deposits (NCDs), apply only to trading banks. They have never applied to building societies or other financial institutions. The penalty of imposing on trading banks a non-prudential requirement was that they were directed by law to pay a certain amount-of their deposits in the days of the SRDs; and of their total liabilities in these days of non-callable deposits-into an account with the Reserve Bank on which a rate of interest very much below market rates was paid. That SRD and now NCD provision has never applied to those other financial institutions. It does impose a financial penalty on the trading banks, and I think many people would argue, and I would agree, that it is reasonable that some penalty or, more accurately, licence fee should be applied to the trading banks. The only thing that is arguable, in my view, is the size of that licence fee.

At the time that the old statutory reserve deposits system-which I think had applied in one form or another since 1945-was changed, banks were required to lodge with the Reserve Bank 7 per cent of their deposits. We changed that, I think it was in 1988, so that over a period of time banks would be required to lodge in an account with the Reserve Bank an amount-it was phased in over three years-equal to one per cent of their total liabilities. Banks had devised ways of holding what were de facto deposits in forms other than those which were defined as deposits for these SRD purposes. At that time the trading banks were paid 5 per cent interest on the money in that compulsory account and the Treasury note rate was around 10 per cent. In other words, the differential between the two rates was 5 per cent.

As a result of the announcement made by the Treasurer last week, the differential rate will be 5 per cent and that will be adjusted every month in accordance with the Treasury note interest rate prevailing for that month in order to maintain a margin of 5 per cent between the money which the trading banks are required to deposit in those accounts with the Reserve Bank and the T-note rate of interest-the de facto licence fee. In other words, the judgment that the Government made back in 1988, as to the size of the de facto licence fee which the banks ought to be required to pay, has been confirmed in the newest arrangements. In the period between the original announcement and today, through what one might call a side effect of the general increase in interest rates, the banks have been required to pay a very much higher de facto licence fee-that is, the difference between the 5 per cent paid by the Reserve Bank on those deposits with the Reserve Bank from the trading banks and the prevailing T-note interest rate.

If anybody wants to criticise the Government for this decision I think she would be on sounder ground if she criticised the Government for not having made, in the first place, a decision that there would be a 5 per cent margin so that the size of the licence fee would remain constant or, alternatively, for not having adjusted the interest rate paid on these deposits by the Reserve Bank somewhat earlier than we did.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Jenkins proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The action of the Defence Minister Beazley in calling in the ADF to deal with the situation at Nurrungar over the weekend: that is, the use of Australian troops against Australian citizens on Australian soil in defence of a US military base which ties Australia into the nuclear-war fighting strategies of the US Government.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The actions of Defence Minister Beazley in calling on the Australian Defence Force to deal with the situation at Nurrungar over the weekend-that is, the use of Australian troops against Australian citizens on Australian soil in defence of a United States military base which ties Australia into the nuclear war fighting strategies of the United States Government-are indeed a matter of public importance. If, as Mr Beazley claimed on radio this morning, everyone knows what goes on at Nurrungar, the limited knowledge we have came not from the Australian Government but from Dr Des Ball of the Australian National University. At the time when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) opened up and told us what Dr Ball had already revealed-that is, that Nurrungar would give the earliest warning of an intercontinental ballistic missile attack on the United States of America (USA) or its allies-the role of Nurrungar was scheduled to be made redundant by the Navstar satellites which detect the same information and have the capability to send it directly or via another satellite to the USA.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very strange then that the Americans are actually in the process of upgrading the capability of the base the function and location of which are now no longer necessary. Can it be, Mr President, as my colleague Senator Haines has suggested, that the most important function of Nurrungar from an Australian point of view is to give us early warning of an attack on Nurrungar and the other Australian nuclear targets which have American flags flying?

If that is not the whole truth, will the Government please tell us something more convincing than that which the Prime Minister has told us or else, for goodness sake, let us get rid of that deadly base for, to return to the most reliable authority we have, Dr Des Ball, Nurrungar has a war-fighting capacity and is, in fact, an essential element in the Star Wars program, known as SDI or strategic defence initiative. That, of course, is denied by the Minister of Defence, but there is nothing new about it. We all know that the American people are told much more about these matters than the Australian people. What better reason could anyone think of for wanting to see Nurrungar closed? If the Government will not act to close it, the people are left only with the option of doing something about it themselves. That is basically why some 500 people made the trip to Nurrungar last weekend and that is why Minister Beazley went into a panic and called in the troops-indeed, the cavalry.

It is intrinsic in basic human rights in a democratic society that we have the right to protest against activities, whether they be government, bureaucratic, corporate or other, and this right was used with great effect by some 500 Australians last week at Nurrungar. The main aim of the protest was to inform Australian citizens about the existence and the function of the so-called joint Australian-US base at Nurrungar and this was achieved. Nurrungar is not listed on the map. In fact, it is designated as a prohibited area. We need only to look at some of the press which emerged as a result of last week's protest. I refer to the Daily Telegraph of Monday, 2 October, which states in an article headed `Watching in secret':
The joint Australian-American bases at Nurrungar, Pine Gap and North-West Cape represent our gravest nuclear threat-yet we know virtually nothing about them.
They are surrounded by heavy security-
not so heavy, we think now-
and a shroud of official silence.
In fact, until this weekend's skirmishes at Nurrungar, in which 492 arrests were made, it's fair bet most Australians had never heard of the installation.
But the Joint Defence Space Communications Centre 500 km north-west of Adelaide is a vital link in America's nuclear strategy.
Later the article states:
. . . it is left to academics such as Andrew Mack, head of the Australian National University's Peace Research Centre, to fill in the gaps.
That is in the knowledge. I continue:
Mr Mack is adamant that Nurrungar and Pine Gap, in particular, present important nuclear targets, such as to the Soviets.
It goes on to say:
`Basically, Nurrungar is very easy to destroy if the Soviet Union launched a nuclear attack.
`Because of this, the United States has developed an alternative system.

It is for these reasons both the anti-nuclear movement and academics such as Mr Mack want the governments to come clean about the bases and our involvement with them. `We must know more,' Mr Mack said.
What exactly is Nurrungar? We read in the Asian Defence Journal of January 1987:

The US bases in Australia are not of the type that require the presence of thousands of soldiers, squadrons of aircraft, and carrier task forces. Its bases in Australia have only a few hundred personnel and are protected by a small force of security personnel. At first glance they would seem inconsequential.
Yet they are not. It is freely acknowledged in Australia, and by the USA and the USSR, that the US bases in Australia are prime nuclear targets.
And further on in the same article:
If Pine Gap is a secret US base, then the United States Air Force base at Nurrungar, SA-
note the words `the United States Air Force base at Nurrungar'-

is a super-secret base. Nurrungar in its early days of development, however, had the advantage that it was located within an area which had already been restricted for security reasons. . . . The rocket range had two advantages as far as security was concerned-it was remote and it was an area in which developments could take place under the guise of further `top secret' rocket tests. The Nurrungar base was begun in 1970 and became operational in 1971.
Later in the same article:

Nurrungar is run by the United States Space Command. The facility has connections with the NSA via the USAF Security Service. There are also some Royal Australian Air Force personnel attached, although it has been suggested, like the employment of some Australians at Pine Gap, that this is purely for `cosmetic purposes' to allow the base to appear as a joint US-Australian facility. It is unlikely that Australian personnel play any major function at Pine Gap or Nurrungar.
(Quorum formed) I guess that the coalition Opposition does not like what I am saying as it has called a quorum. I again quote from the Asian Defence Journal:

As a consequence Nurrungar is a crucial element in United States' security. Since 1983 Nurrungar has been included in the US Strategic Defence Initiative (`Starwars') programme. This is, of course, despite the fact that the present Australian government is opposed to `Starwars' and has refused to allow Australian facilities to be used in this programme.

TALK.START.PARA: —It said it is.

—Yes, it says it is. The Hawke Government has only twice made official statements in Parliament on the role of the United States bases in Australia. On June 6 1984 Mr Hawke claimed that `the removal of the joint facilities . . . would damage the capacity of the United States for monitoring and verification, so striking a very serious blow at the prospect of arms control agreements between the superpowers'. On 22 November 1988, Mr Hawke once again described the bases as important for verification and claimed that `verification was the key issue in reaching the INF (Intermediate Range Nuclear Forces) agreement last year, and verification will be the key to any START (Strategic Arms Reduction Talks) agreements in the future'. These claims were made despite the findings of a major report by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in Federal Parliament in 1986 entitled Disarmament and Arms Control in the Nuclear Age, that the base's role in nuclear verification had been used to deflect attention from the more offensive functions.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the protest over the last week, the people who attended chose to protest peacefully. By consensus the decision was made that no-one would resist arrest. These forms of peaceful protest-that is, forms of civil disobedience-are used all over the world. They were used by the Polish people in the Solidarity protests; by the Hungarians and the Czechs in their protests against Soviet Union domination; by people in the United States, Australia and other countries over the Vietnam war; and by Australian citizens who chose to protest against the Australia Card. The protesters believed that the base at Nurrungar should be closed because it is a nuclear target; it fails to acknowledge Aboriginal land rights claims; it is a nuclear war fighting base; it is a Star Wars base; it costs the Australian taxpayer at least $30m per annum to maintain; it does not contribute to arms control verification at all; and it infringes on our national sovereignty.

As far as the chain of events over the week is concerned, the protesters were stunned by the ease with which they were able to penetrate security at the base. One protester who entered the radome said:

I was expecting to be apprehended well before getting near the base but there appeared to be no security around. I was able to climb the fence and enter an open door into the radomes before being discovered.

Other protesters said they had to shout and sing to draw attention to their presence in the base in order to get arrested. Completely unfounded allegations have been made that the protesters acted violently and attacked a police horse with stones. Media coverage of the event would clearly have shown that such behaviour was impossible. The protesters were committed to non-violent direct action; indeed, they stayed true to that. I believe that the allegations that the protesters had behaved violently were made simply as a ploy to divert attention from the purpose of the protesters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it the policy of the Government and the Army that, where qualified Army Reserve officers are available they are preferred over available regular Army officers for senior Army Reserve appointments and in particular, the command of Army Reserve formations; if so, who, by what process and criteria, determines the qualification of these Army reserve officers; in particular, what is the degree and level of input from senior rank levels of the Army Reserve.

(2) Is it a fact that both the Fourth Brigade in Victoria and the Fifth Brigade in New South Wales, both Army Reserve formations, are now commanded by regular Army full colonels in each case replacing Army Reserve Brigadiers.
(3) Who made the decision, on what advice and for what reasons, to replace these senior Reserve officers with regular officers.
(4) Did the A and P Committee deliberate on these changes; if so, will the Minister table the minutes thereof and what was the recommendations of the A and P Committee in each instance.

(5) At the time these replacements occurred were there other Army Reserve brigadiers or full colonels on the active or inactive list available to take up command of these brigades; if so, was any of them approached to ascertain their availability to fill these appointments; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. It is the policy of the Government and the Army that, where qualified and suitable Army Reserve officers are available, they will be preferred over available Regular officers for senior Reserve appointments, including command. The qualifications of Reserve officers are determined, in the first instance, by their Commanders at each level who report upon them annually. The Army Reserve Appointment and Promotion Advisory Committee also meets annually and makes recommendations to the Chief of the General Staff. Senior Reserve officers who make a direct contribution to that Committee are the Assistant Chief of the General Staff-Army Reserve and the Commanders of the 2nd and 3rd Divisions. Land Commander Australia, the General Officer Commanding Logistic and Training Command, the Commander of the 1st Division and the Military District commanders throughout Australia frequently consult their respective senior Reserve officers when appointments are being considered.
(2) Yes.

(3) The Chief of the General Staff made the decision on advice from the Land Commander Australia, the Assistant Chief of the General Staff for the Army Reserve and the Commanders of the 2nd and 3rd Divisions. The decision to replace the Reserve officers with Regular officers was made on the basis that no suitable Reserve officer was available because of age or limited experience or because they had already commanded or were required for other appointments.

(4) Although not reflected in the Minutes specifically, the Army Reserve Appointment and Promotion Advisory Committee kept under review all Senior Army Reserve appointments and did, as a matter of course, deliberate on these changes. It also considered the probability of other Reserve formations and units being commanded by Regular Officers when on a case by case basis a pool of suitable Reserve Officers was not available.
(5) All Active and Inactive Army Reserve brigadiers and colonels were considered but none was preferred to the reasons given in the reply to Parliamentary Question 1171 (3).
